DataElement.preferredName: Biospecimen Findings Supplemental Qualifiers Dataset Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization Chromosome 17 Assessment Status
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The results of Fluorescence in Situ Hybridization testing for Chromosome 17 (BRAF) mutation(s).

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Biospecimen Findings Supplemental Qualifiers Dataset Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization Chromosome 17 Assessment Outcome
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A dataset containing supplemental information, specifically non-standard variables, to parent records in the biospecimen findings domain._A physical mapping approach that uses fluorescent tags to detect hybridization of probes within metaphase chromosomes or less condensed somatic interphase chromatin. This technique can be used for identification of chromosomal abnormalities and for gene mapping._The designation for each member of the seventeenth largest human autosomal chromosome pair. Chromosome 17 spans more than 81 million base pairs and represents between 2.5 and 3% of the total DNA in normal diploid cells._The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of._The result of an action.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Positive For BRAF Gene Gene Duplication Abnormality

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Positive For BRAF Gene Gene Duplication Abnormality
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Involving advantage or good.: The reason of something.: This gene is involved in cell organization/biogenesis and the inhibition of apoptosis.: Generation of an extra copy of a particular gene in the genome. A gene duplication abnormality may occur by gene amplification, random breakage and reunion, retrotransposition or unequal crossing-over at meiosis. A gene duplication abnormality can be either heritable or somatic.

Concepts.definition: Involving advantage or good.
The reason of something.
This gene is involved in cell organization/biogenesis and the inhibition of apoptosis.

Generation of an extra copy of a particular gene in the genome. A gene duplication abnormality may occur by gene amplification, random breakage and reunion, retrotransposition or unequal crossing-over at meiosis. A gene duplication abnormality can be either heritable or somatic.
